body: Good call. I'm going to make `_.chain` and `_.prototype.chain` force chaining, by internally setting a `__chain__` property.

Will this break compatibility for ppl who use it as-is? 
I dont personally but just checking

We recently added `_.chain` back as essentially a no-op, for devs writing code to work for both Underscore and Lo-Dash. That covers some cases, this would cover more. I don't see it as a big compat change as most devs using Lo-Dash don't use `_.chain` because it was removed for so long.
Also our next bump is 1.4 so I'm ok introducing this. It allows us to have our cake and eat it too. Having intuitive chaining for common use and explicit chaining for others.
Cool! Will it work for `_(obj)` chaining too or just `_.chain(obj)`?

Once you call `_.chain(..)` or `_(...).chain(...)` it will set the `__chain__` flag to `true` for that wrapper and force all methods to return a wrapper with its `__chain__` set to true too. It's per wrapper so it won't cover the case of just calling `_(...)` which will still be intuitive. I think the `_(...)` case is easy enough to handle by spreading the word to use `_.xyz(...)`, instead of `_(...).xyz` for one off function calls if you don't intend to chain.

Hm, I may have confused you here.

_(...) is equiv to _.chain(...) according to the docs so I was wondering if anything will change there.
I understand that _.foo(...) behavior will stay the same.
Right, at the moment `_.chain(...)` is simply an alias for `_`, that will change with this.
Hm... I see. What would be the difference between the two patterns though? I quite liked the equivalence so far.
Hey JDD - what is your timeline for 1.4? I've been working on TypeScript definitions for lodash and I wanna wait for 1.4 to release them

You can use the current stable [edge version](https://github.com/bestiejs/lodash/blob/022828e5113f7d2e5972cb8c4dfd69330edf33b9/dist/lodash.js). I've added `_.forEachRight` (aliased as `_.eachRight`), `_.findLast`, `_.findLastIndex`, `_.findLastKey`, `_.forOwnRight`, `_.forInRight`, `_.pull`, `_.remove`, and `_.curry`. I'd dig adding the definition file to the 1.4 release if possible.

Depends - how long till the 1.4? Super busy right now so it will take me some time. 
Also, have you edited the docs for the added functions somewhere I can look at?
The docs are in the edge repo as well under docs/. They're based on the docs inlined in the source. I have family visiting so a bump isn't realistic for at least another 2 weeks.
Great, i ll let you know how i get on!
Work has been kicking my butt, haven't made any progress. Just FYI.

OK I started writing the TS tests but got stuck pretty quickly because of the documentation. How would you feel about working on the docs a little first? I'm guessing you maintain those yourself rather than copy from underscore right?

Let's take `clone` as example.

```
_.clone(obj); //ok
_.clone(obj, true); // ok
_.clone(obj, true, function(value) { }); // ok

_.clone(obj, function(value) { }); // ok?
_.clone(obj, function(value, index, object) { }); // ok?
```

We can start by adding examples to the docs and then making the TS defs should be a breeze. Win-win :)
@georgiosd passing `true` and `callback` is supported. The args the `callback` accepts is [documented](http://lodash.com/docs/#clone).
John, any feedback?

> Not sure what the guard does in defaults()

It's used to allow it to work as a callback in methods like `_.reduce` which pass `accumulator`, `value`, -->`index`<--, `object` to callbacks.

> Can't seem to get findKey working with pluck/where type callbacks. I'm thinking the where case is not viable but I thought I'd ask

Yap it works, try:

``` js
_.findKey({ 'a': { 'x': 0 }, 'b': { 'x': 1 } }, 'x');
// => 'b'
```

Feedback on the tests:

`_.findKey` can accept a `thisArg`.
`_.isEqual` can accept a `callback` and `thisArg`.
`_.merge` can accept a `thisArg` when passed a `callback`.
`_.transform` the `accum` is optional.
I'm looking at the 2.2.1 for _.where - it looks like it doesn't support callbacks any more? Is that right?Is there a changelog of breaking changes in 2.x/2.2.x?
In the source `_.where` is simply `var where = filter`, so technically it supports what `_.filter` supports. I believe `_.pluck` and `_.where` are the only non-alias aliases :P

Then I guess the docs are wrong - this is all they say on argument 2:
properties (Object): The object of property values to filter by.

> Then I guess the docs are wrong 

They aren't for the use of the method. The `_.where` method has a narrower common use then `_.filter` and originally started out as a separate method. To avoid build complexities and for dev familiarity I've opted to keep it designated as a separate method for the time being.
This thread has been automatically locked since there has not been any recent activity after it was closed. Please open a new issue for related bugs.
